references.B08JEN01USGP: Jensen, J. B., C. D. Camp, W. Gibbons, and M. J. Elliot, editors. 2008. Amphibians and reptiles of Georgia. University of Georgia Press, Athens. 575 pp.
references.A02CAM01SEGP: Camp, C.D., S.G. Tilley, R.M Austin,  and J.L. Marshall. 2002. A new species of black-bellied salamander (genus Desmognathus) from the Appalacian mountains of northern Georgia. Herpetologica. 58:471-484.
references.A04CAM02USGP: Camp, C. D. 2004. Desmognathus folkertsi. Catalogue of American Amphibians and Reptiles 782:1-3.
references.A07ROT01USGP: Rothermel, B. B., J. B. Jensen, C. D. Camp, and T. D. Schwaner. 2007. Geographic distribution. Desmognathus folkertsi. Herpetological Review 38(2): 213.

habitat_description: Formerly included in Desmognathus quadramaculatus; recognized as a distinct species on the basis of adult size, body proportions, color pattern, and fixed differences at four allozyme loci (Camp et al. 2002, Camp 2004). The Dwarf Black-bellied salamander is found in or along the banks of rocky, clear, cool, swift moving streams near waterfalls and seeps.  Refuges are in rock crevices or burrows.  Occurs with the Black-bellied salamander, but is smaller and restricted to just a few drainages (Camp 2002, Camp 2004). This species utilizes very similar habitats as the formerly conspecific D. quadramaculatus (Jensen et al. 2008).
